bibl.title: George Arnold v. Territory of Washington Jefferson County. Type of Document
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

body.p: In the District Court of the third Judicial District of Washington Territory holding terms at Port Townsend
In the matter of the application of George Arnold for a writ of Habeas Corpus
To the Hon. R.S. Greene, chief of Justice of the Supreme Court of Washington Territory and Judge of the 3rd Judicial District- therein
The complaint of George Arnold respectfully shows

1st That on the day of June AD 1881 he was arrested, taken into custody and ever since said day has been and now is confined and imprisoned at Port Townsend in the County of Jefferson, Washington Territory
2nd That the complaint is so imprisoned by Col. Pollock, of the U.S. Army

3rd The pretense of said imprisonment, is that it is charged by said Col. Pollock that complaint was in the year 1873 or 1874 an enlisted soldier in the Army of the United States, and that at San Juan County in this

Territory he is diserted therefrom and is a diserter from the Army of the United States. and as your petition is informed and believes, is is the institution of said Pollock to convene a military court Martial your petitioners for said alleged offense.
4th That the said imprisonment is illegal for the following reason

That ever since said alleged desertion your petitioner has lived openly in the County of Jefferson, Washington Territory and might at any time have been prosecuted for said alleged offense and that moe than two years have elapsed since said offense was committed, if comiitted at all.

Wherefor your petitioner prays that a writ of Habeas Corpus may be issued, to inspire into the causes of said imprisonment and that said Pollock may be required to produce complaint before your Honor and that your Honor will discharge the complainant from the imprisonment
aforesaid, and grant such other and further relief as may be just and lawful in the premises
C.M. Bradshaw Attorney for complaints
Territory of Washington } County of Jefferson

Charles M. Bradshaw being first duly sworn deposes and says that he is th attorney for George Arnold the relator herein, and makes the affidavit in his behalf and makes the forgoing application for a writ of Habeas Corpus in his behald and at his request.
That he has read said application knows the contents thereof and believes the same to be true.
C.M. Bradshaw
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 5th day of July AD 1881
James Seavey Clerk
No. 405 District Courts
Matter of the application of George Arnold for writ of Habeas Corpus,
Complaint Filed July 5th 1881
James Seavey Clerk
